titleStmt.title: Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.3

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.3

summary.seg:
Cambridge, St John's College MS D.3, is a collection of medical texts made in England in the 13th century. The manuscript was probably made at St Augustine's Canterbury, and was certainly part of the extensive library collection there as it bears two St Augustine's pressmarks in different hands on its opening leaves, ff. [ii] recto and [ii] verso. In addition to the pressmarks, there is a medieval list of the contents of the volume on f. [ii] recto written in a neat early 15th century hand which lists the contents of the volume as follows:
Rasis in Almasorio
Diuisiones Rasis
Tractatus de flebotomia
Megategni Galieni
De regimine acutorum
Diagnosticon Galieni
Liber epidamarum
Lucidarius Bertrandi
Liber pronosticorum
Liber de signis complexionis
Regule ad sciendum cuius complexionis sit medicamen
This list of the contents indicates that Cambridge, St John's College MS D.3 was mutilated or damaged after the list was added to f. [ii] recto in the 15th century as the 'Rasis in Almasorio' (Rāzī, Liber almansoris) is no longer present in the volume, and the 'Diuisiones Rasis' (Rāzī, Liber diuisionum) lacks its opening leaves, indicating the loss of probably two or more quires from the original codicological arrangement.

The medical texts in Cambridge, St John's College MS D.3 a combination of the 'best' old and new medicine available in north western Europe at the time; classic medical treatises by Galen are encountered alongside the medicine of the Persian physician Rāzī whose works were translated into Latin in the 12th and 13th centuries. Interspersed with the larger medical treatises and medicinal preparations are occasional additional medical recipes added to the margins and blank spaces, e.g., ff. 27r (blank space between texts) and 28v (lower margin), and these recipes show an extended influence in Greek, Arab, and Persian medicine in England as the additional recipes are for preparations involving sugar, aloe-wood, galangal, cubeb, saffron, and many other ingredients native to Africa and Asia rather than north-western Europe, and which were only just becoming available in England in the 13th century through complex multi-step trade routes.

Although it is damaged, the binding of Cambridge, St John's College MS D.3 is notable as it is an example of an English strap-and-pin binding, a type of binding popular in England in the high middle ages. The binding materials consist of alum-tawed skin over wood boards, the typical binding resources for monastic bindings in England at this time. The volume was originally fastened by two tawed-skin straps anchored into the fore edge of the front board, which would have terminated in small metal endpieces with a hole punched through, or with a metal ring looped through the end of the strap. The punched-holes, or metal rings at the ends of the straps would have hooked over small metal pins protruding from the centre of the rear cover, and held the book closed when not in use; both the straps and the pins have been lost, but two puncture marks from the pin plates can be seen just offset from the centre-vertical of the rear cover. The mounting positions of the straps and pins are often an indication of the origin of the binding as English bindings typically anchored the straps to the front board and pierced the pin-plates through the rear board, with the reverse arrangement much more common in mainland European bindings. There is a similar binding on Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.24, another 13th century medical manuscript owned by the community of St Augustine's, although like MS D.3, its strap-and-pin fastenings are now only visible as mounting-grooves and punctures for the pin-plates.

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures Project
Cambridge University Library

p.secFol: (3r) aque frigide oportet tunc ut in potu tribuatur uinum purum

supportDesc.support: Parchment leaves in the main bookblock.

foliation.note: Partial foliation in pencil in the upper outer corner of the first recto of each quire from Quire 2 onward. Folio designations [i], [ii], and [iii] were assigned to unfoliated leaves for the purposes of this electronic record when the manuscript was examined in 2023 for the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project.

note.p: The partial foliation of the manuscript has led to errors in the foliation sequence. The errors are located in the leaves between the designations ff. 18-32 and are resolved by f. 32. For the purposes of this electronic record, the leaves between f. 18 and 32 are counted sequentially and any folio designations in pencil on those leaves have been disregarded. Folios 1-18 and 32-135 follow the foliation sequence as written in the manuscript.

collation.p:
This manuscript consists of three contemporary codicological units which share layouts and some scribes and artists, but can clearly be seen to be distinct and self-contained codicological productions; these three units are each separated by a comma in the following collation statement.
Fragment (former pastedown; f. [i]) |
Parchment endleaf (f. [ii]) +
Quire 18-1 (1st leaf missing; ff. 1-7)
Quire 26 (ff. 8-13)
Quire 38 (ff. 14-21)
Quire 410 (ff. 22-31) ,
Quires 5-88 (ff. 32-63)
Quire 96 (ff. 64-69) ,
Quires 10-168 (ff. 70-125)
Quire 1710 (ff. 126-135) |
Fragment (former pastedown liner); f. [iii])

signatures.p: Quires numbered in pencil in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords present in the centre of the lower margin of the last leaf of Quires 5-17, some lost to trimming: catchwords in Quires 5-9 are enclosed in a 'zigzag' frame; catchwords in Quires 10-17 are enclosed in a rectangular frame.

binding.p: Late 13th or early 14th century binding, repaired in 1971. Fully bound in an underlayer of tawed skin and then an outer layer of ?parchment over wood boards. Three sewing stations, and three narrow slightly raised bands on spine. No head or tail tabs or bands visible. Two small printed paper labels affixed to spine, 'D' and '3' for the current shelfmark, and stuck over 'D' and '3' written in ink in an early modern hand. Traces of a former title in brown ink on the spine now almost entirely illegible. The binding may once have been fitted with two strap and pin fastenings: there are two raised 'bumps' in the fore edge of the front cover, probably where the strap ends were mounted, and there are two small puncture marks along the centre-vertical of the rear cover, which were probably caused by the pin plate fittings. Both the parchment cover and the tawed-skin underlayer sit over the remains of the fastenings, in some cases without holes or damage in the cover-surfaces, so the covers may have been repaired or repositioned after the fastenings were lost or removed.

Paper pastedowns added in 1971 at the beginning and end of the volume. The front pastedown contains a St John's College bookplate, and William Crashaw's donation bookplate. The rear pastedown contains a note in pencil recording the repair of the volume: 'Repaired, endpapers lifted, by J. P. Gray & Son Ltd December 1971 for £5'.

The former pastedowns are ff. [i] and 135. Folio [iii] appears to have been used to line the binding underneath the right pastedown. All of the medieval pastedowns and liners have been lifted and are now free and both sides of the leaves are visible.
Dimensions (L x W x D): 260 x 180 x 40 mm
Housed in a black archival box with custom-fitted padded inserts to stabilise the volume.

provenance.p: Owned by St. Augustine's Abbey St. Augustine's Abbey (Canterbury, England) in Canterbury, England. On f. [ii] recto there is a title and shelfmark for the volume: Medicina translata. Di: XIIII, Gra. II. Liber S. Aug. Cant. (Translations of medical [texts]. Case 14, Shelf 2. Book [belonging to] St Augustine's Canterbury) followed by a list of the contents of the volume. On f. [ii] verso there is a note: Contenta huius libri. Rasis in Almasorio. Item liber diuisionum Rasis cum aliis de libraria S. Aug. Cant. D. XIIII, Gra. I. (Contents of this book: Rasis in Almasorio . [The] same [author] Divisions of Rasis with other works from the library of St Augustine's Canterbury . Case 14, Shelf 1). See James, Ancient Libraries, p. 520, no. 1228 CBMLC 13.II BA1.1228

Purchased at an unknown time before 1624 by William Crashaw Crashaw, William, 1572-1626 , a lawyer, book collector, and former Johnian. Crashaw's collection numbered around 200 manuscripts and 1000 printed books.

The manuscripts and printed books owned by William Crashaw were purchased by Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton Southampton, Henry Wriothesley, Earl of, 1573-1624 , at an unknown time before Wriothesley's death in 1624. Wriothesley had been a student-contemporary of Crashaw at St John's College and he purchased Crashaw's collection with the intention to present the volumes as a gift to the Library of St John's College. The library was still partly under construction at the time of the purchase resulting in the Wriothesley family storing Crashaw's collection and delivering it piecemeal to the College over a number of years.

After Henry Wriothesley's death in 1624 and William Crashaw's death in 1626, care of Crashaw's books and manuscripts passed to Wriothesley's son, Thomas Wriothesley, 4th Earl of Southampton Southampton, Thomas Wriothesley, Earl of, 1607-1667 . Although Crashaw's printed books seem to have been passed to the College without incident, Thomas Wriothesley seems to have taken a particular interest in the manuscripts, adding his name typically in the form 'Tho: C. S.' for Thomas comes southamptoniensis ('Thomas, Earl of Southampton') to most of them, and apparently exhibiting such reluctance to deliver the manuscripts that the College wrote to his mother, Elizabeth Vernon Southampton, Elizabeth Vernon Wriothesley, Countess of, 1573-1655? to ask her to encourage her son to hand over the volumes.

history.acquisition: Given to St John’s College in 1635 by Thomas Wriothesley, 4th Earl of Southampton Southampton, Thomas Wriothesley, Earl of, 1607-1667 on behalf of William Crashaw Crashaw, William, 1572-1626 and Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton Southampton, Henry Wriothesley, Earl of, 1573-1624 . The initials ‘Tho. C. S.’ in ink (for Thomas Comes Southamptoniensis) are present on f. [i] verso. William Crashaw's bookplate recording the donation is present on the left pastedown.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M. R. James, Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of St John's College, Cambridge (Cambirdge, 1913) and B. C. Barker-Benfield, St Augustine's Abbey vols. I-III, Corpus of British Medieval Library Catalogues 13 (2008)

availability.p: Visitors to St John's College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: St John's College: Old Library and Special Collections.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.3, ff. [i] and [iii]
msIdentifier.msName: Part 1 - Fragments: The Liber Pauperum of Vacarius

msItem.title: Fragment: Liber Pauperum (Book 6, chs 27-28)
msItem.author: Vacarius (1115?–1200?)
msItem.incipit: [i] recto MPR cum inter institutum et substitutum
msItem.explicit: [iii] verso ex legitimo formato testimonio precedat nullum
msItem.note: Fragmentary leaves used as the front pastedown [i] and as a binding liner under the right pastedown [iii].
The Liber Pauperum was edited for the Selden Society.

listBibl.bibl: F. de Zulueta (ed.), The Liber Pauperum of Vacarius (Selden Soc. 44, 1927), esp. p. xxix

extent.seg: Fragment, comprising two separate leaves from another manuscript used as pastedown and binding liner (now lifted):

supportDesc.condition: Both leaves cut from their original size for use in the binding; folio [iii] was cut to a smaller size than folio [i]. Folio [i] seems to have sustained damage from a clasp or fastening along the fore-edge margin of the leaf, but there is no other evidence in the remainder of Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.3 of a fastening having been fitted in that position. Folio [iii] has small puncture-holes caused by the pin-fittings in two strap and pin fastenings. Both leaves are coated in an adhesive residue.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Ruled in two-column format with wide margins for a parallel gloss-text.

handNote.p: Written in a neat northern textualis libraria with some late protogothic features.

decoNote.p: No significant decoration in this Part.

note.p: A brief inscription 'Jo Lond' in ink on f. [i] verso, perhaps the name of a former owner, but see CBMLC 13.III, pp. 1841-44 for a discussion of the number of people known by this name and associated with St Augustine's Abbey.
The shelfmark 'D3' is present in faint ink on f. [i] verso.
A possible former shelfmark 'A44', now struck out, in ink on f. [i] verso.

origin.note: Date and place of production assigned based on palaeographical features.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.3, pp. [ii] + 1-31, 32-69, 70-135

msContents.textLang: Latin, with a note in Hebrew

msItem.title: Pressmark and detailed list of the contents of the volume

note.p:
Full transcription:
Medicina translata : Di : XIIII : Gra II : liber sancti augustini cant
The 'D number' has been altered so that it now reads 'XIIII', the original designation is unclear, but included the 'X'.
Written in a late 13th century hand with later alterations.

msItem.title: Medieval list of the contents of the volume

note.p:
Full transcription:
Rasis in Almasorio
Diuisiones Rasis
Tractatus de flebotomia
Megategni Galieni
De regimine acutorum
Diagnosticon Galieni
Liber epidamarum
Lucidarius Bertrandi
Liber pronosticorum
Liber de signis complexionis
Regule ad sciendum cuius complexionis sit medicamen
Written in an ?early 15th century hand, by the same scribe who added a similar contents list to Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.24, f. [i] recto .

This contents list indicates that the volume was mutilated or damaged after the list was added in the early 15th century. The 'Rasis in Almasorio' (Rāzī, Liber almansoris) is no longer present in the volume, and the 'Diuisiones Rasis' (Rāzī, Liber diuisionum) lack their opening leaves, indicating the loss of probably two or more quires.

msItem.title: Brief summary of the contents of the volume and ownership inscription

note.p:
Full transcription:
Contentur huius libri
Rasis in almasori
Item libri diusionum rasis
Cum alijs de libraria sancti Augustini Cant
D Xiiij Ga I
Written in a ?late 14th century hand

msItem.title: Liber diuisionum (tr. Gerard of Cremona) [Latin]
msItem.author: Abū Bakr Muḥammad ibn Zakarīyā Rāzī (865?–925?)

note.p: The text begins abruptly, the first few leaves having been lost.

Although this manuscript is not mentioned directly, see L. Thorndike, 'Latin Manuscripts of Works by Rasis', Bulletin of the History of Medicine, 32.1 (1958), pp. 54-67 for a discussion of the circulation of groups of texts by Rasis in western Europe in the middle ages.

msItem.title: Antidotarium (tr. Gerard of Cremona) [Latin]
msItem.author: Abū Bakr Muḥammad ibn Zakarīyā Rāzī (865?–925?)
msItem.finalRubric: 27r Explicit liber diuisionum translatus a magister Gerardo Cremonensi de arabico in latinum in ciuitate tolletana postea latus cremonam a magister Petro iam dicti gerardi nepote . in ecclesia S. lucie de cremona patet multis eum petentibus.
msItem.note: This items begins with a list of 61 capitulae on f. 18r, and then the main text begins on f. 18v

Although Cambridge, St John's College MS D.3 is not mentioned directly in the article, see L. Thorndike, 'Latin Manuscripts of Works by Rasis', Bulletin of the History of Medicine, 32.1 (1958), pp. 54-67 for a discussion of the circulation of groups of texts by Rasis in western Europe in the middle ages.

note.p: Recipes for 'Unguentum egyptiacum' and 'Syrupus almurafa'.
The first recipe is in the hand of the main scribe, the second is in the hand of the scribe who added annotations throughout the first few extant quires.

msItem.title: De cura(tione) lapidis [Latin]
msItem.author: ʻAbd al-Malik ibn Abī al-ʻAlāʾ Ibn Zuhr, (–1162)
msItem.rubric: 27r Canon quem scripsit Alguazir .i. consul . Abrinaleprenomen . Zornomen . filius abi melech filij Zor inperatori Sarazenorum ab. filio yosephi filij tesiphini . de curatione lapidis

note.p: Recipe in lower margin

msItem.title: Extracts from the Synonima [Latin]
msItem.author: Abū Bakr Muḥammad ibn Zakarīyā Rāzī (865?–925?)

msItem.title: Treatise on phlebotomy
msItem.note: This text is sometimes ascribed to Ricardus Anglicus Ricardus Anglicus.

msItem.title: Regimen acutorum (tr.) [Latin]
msItem.author: Hippocrates
msItem.note: This translation is variously attributed to Gerard of Cremona and Constantinus Africanus.

msItem.title: Liber diagnosticon
msItem.author: Galen
msItem.incipit: 64v Rationem quidem puto medicinam esse debere

note.p: Text is unfinished and ends abruptly.
See discussion in CBMLC 13.II, BA1.1228, pp. 1249-1250 about the identification of this text, and its possible relationship with Celsus, De medicina.

msItem.title: Book 6 of the Epidemia(rum)
msItem.author: Pseudo-Hippocrates
msItem.incipit: 67r Liber epydimiarum a multis multotiens uobis approbatus
msItem.note: See also Dublin, Trinity College MS 403, ff. 29r-37v.

msItem.title: Lucidarius uel Almagest
msItem.author: Bertrandus
msItem.note: List of capitula at the beginning of the text.
This text and the Liber pronosticorum appear together in reverse order in Vienna, Österreichische Nationalbibliothek, Cod. 2296, ff. 100r-115v. See CBMLC 13.II, BA1.1228, pp. 1249-1250.

msItem.title: Liber pronosticorum
msItem.incipit: 116v Futurorum significaciones ualde decorant mentem prouidentis
msItem.note: List of capitula at the beginning of the text.

This text and the Incipit lucidarius bertrandi uel Almagest appear together in reverse order in Vienna, Österreichische Nationalbibliothek, Cod. 2296, ff. 100r-115v. See CBMLC 13.II, BA1.1228, pp. 1249-1250.

msItem.title: De signis complexionis
msItem.explicit: 127v Unde ad praesens super sedeamus . alias tractaturi de ipsis

listBibl.bibl: L. Thorndike, Isis 49 (1958), pp. 398-408, esp. pp. 402-403

msItem.title: Liber Pulsuum
msItem.author: Philaretus
msItem.incipit: 127v Pulsus est motio cordis et arteriarum
msItem.finalRubric: 128r Laus tibi sit Christe quoniam liber explicit iste.

msItem.title: Treatise on finding the complexion of a compound medicine
msItem.incipit: 128v Ad sciendum cuius complexionis sit medicamen compositum

listBibl.bibl: L. Thorndike, Isis 49 (1958), pp. 398-408, esp. pp. 403 and n. 33

msItem.title: Notes on the interpretations of various colours of urine
Medical recipes
msItem.note: Medical recipes in several hands. Folio 133r is blank

p.secFol: 2v aque frigide oportet tunc ut in potu tribuatur uinum purum

support.material: Parchment (HFFH) of variable quality, some leaves flexible, well-prepared, and whole, others stiff, speckled and full of holes.

collation.p:
Three codicological units:
Quire 18-1 (1st leaf missing; ff. 1-7)
Quire 26 (ff. 8-13)
Quire 38 (ff. 14-21)
Quire 410 (ff. 22-31) ,
Quires 5-88 (ff. 32-63)
Quire 96 (ff. 64-69) ,
Quires 10-168 (ff. 70-125)
1710 (ff. 126-135)

catchwords.seg: The catchwords present in the lower margin of the last verso of each quire in ff. 32r-69v are enclosed in a zig-zag bubble; some catchwords trimmed away. The catchwords present in the lower margin of the last verso of each quire in ff. 70r-135v are enclosed in a rectangular frame; some catchwords trimmed away. No catchwords visible ff. 1r-31v.

supportDesc.condition: Some guide-letters and catchwords have been (partially) lost to trimming. Some leaves have medieval repairs (sewn) with the yarn still present in the leaf.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Written in two-column format, typically 47 lines to the column and typically, but not exclusively, above topline.

handNote.p: This main text in this manuscript is written in 13th-century northern textualis libraria by several scribes, whose hands are of similar appearance and quality.

There are annotations throughout the manuscript by a scribe writing a slightly informal northern textualis libraria, who typically works in a lighter ink and sometimes supplies missing passages of text, marginal annotations, or short texts and medical recipes in the margins and in empty spaces in the volume. This scribe's hand can be identified in this volume by his (relatively) long ascenders and descenders, see e.g., his addition in the lower margin of f. 28v. This scribe also supplies the guide text for rubricated headings, e.g., f. 32r, upper margin, now partially trimmed away.

decoNote.p: Large flourished initials in red and blue at the opening of each codicological unit, i.e, f. 32r and f. 70r, the first one absent due to leaves lost from the volume. Smaller flourished initials at the beginning of most new texts and major sections of text.
Plain initials in red or blue at the beginning of minor divisions in the texts.
Rubricated titles to most texts and rubricated chapter and section headings within texts.

decoDesc.decoNote: Paraph marks in red and blue to divide the minor sections of some texts in the volume.

note.p: Folio 135v: record of a transaction in Hebrew, now badly damaged due to abrasion.

origin.note: Date and place of production assigned based on palaeographical features.

change.persName: Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer, Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries Project
